title: How to Prune Shrub Roses

steps.headline: Prune shrub roses in late winter or early spring.
steps.description: This is the best time because the new buds and leaves are just starting to come in, making them distinguishable from the old growth. If you only need to deadhead your shrub rose, you should do it in late summer, right after the rose is done flowering.

steps.headline: Get some hand pruners and loppers.
steps.description: Make sure that the hand pruners are made to cut canes up to ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick. If you can't get loppers, or simply don't like using them, get a small pruning saw instead. You'll need the loppers/pruning saw to cut thicker canes and stems.

steps.headline: Protect yourself with heavy-duty gloves and safety goggles.
steps.description: It would also be a good idea to wear a pair of long pants and closed-toed work boots. The long sleeves and pants will protect your skin against the rose's sharp thorns, while the goggles will shield your eyes against any whipping stems. If you don't have any long-sleeved shirts, get gloves that reach your elbows.

steps.headline: Disinfect your tools using bleach and water.
steps.description: You should do this even if the tools look clean; there may be bacteria on them that might infect your shrub rose. Prepare a cleaning solution using 1 part bleach and 9 parts water. Dip the tools into the solution to clean and disinfect them, then wipe them dry with a paper towel.

steps.headline: Cut at 45-degree angles, ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) above outward-facing buds.
steps.description: Outward-facing buds are buds that are facing you (or away from the center of the plant). The highest part of the angle should be on the same side as the bud. This will help prevent water from dripping into the bud which could lead to rot and decay. You will be using this technique for all parts of the rose, unless otherwise noted. Consider practicing on a few dead stems to get the hang of it. Don't cut closer than ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm), or you risk damaging the bud. Don't cut further either, or you risk the stem developing disease or hosting pests.

steps.headline: Cut down diseased stems with loppers or bypass pruners.
steps.description: To remove all traces of the disease, and to reduce the chances of it coming back, cut the cane down to a bud that is at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) below the diseased portion. Use loppers on canes thicker than a pencil, and bypass pruners on thinner canes. Dead and diseased canes appear black or shriveled throughout. Healthy canes appear green on the outside and white on the inside.

steps.headline: Seal your cuts with white school glue or prune paint seal.
steps.description: This will aid in healing and shield the cane against cane borers. You should do this for every cut you make from this point onward. Simply apply a drop of glue straight from the bottle to the cut portion of the cane. Prune paint seal is typically spray on, like spray paint. If it came in a can, you will have to apply it with a clean paintbrush.

steps.headline: Use bypass pruners to clear crowded canes from the center.
steps.description: You do not have to cut all of the stems or canes in the middle of the shrub, but you should cut any that are crisscrossing or that appear crowded. Your goal here is to open up the shrub for air circulation. Make sure that your shrub looks symmetrical and balanced.

steps.headline: Trim away all of the thin canes with bypass pruners.
steps.description: Locate the canes that are thinner than a pencil. Cut these canes off with a bypass pruner. If your area is prone to cane borers, it would be a good idea to seal the cut ends with white school glue or prune paint sealer.

steps.headline: Use the bypass pruners to remove suckers.
steps.description: Suckers are stems that grow from the roots. They appear further from the main set of canes. You need to trim these as close to the base of the shrub as possible. If needed, dig through the soil to reach them. Be sure to cover the roots back up when you are done, however.

steps.headline: Switch to a pruning saw and cut down the old, woody canes.
steps.description: Try to cut the old, woody canes as close to the base of the shrub as possible. Seal the cut ends with white school glue or prune paint seal. Old, woody canes may appear grayish. They are hard inside, and may have a visible woodgrain or mini tree rings.

steps.headline: Clear the remaining foliage with bypass pruners.
steps.description: Use a rake to pull the cut foliage out from under the shrub. Throw the foliage away into a bin; do not toss it into a compost heap.

steps.headline: Deadhead the shrub rose as needed with hand pruners or scissors.
steps.description: The best time to do this would be during the summer, after flowering is done. You can do it at other times during the year, however. Trim the cane down until you reach a stem with 5 to 7 leaves on it.

steps.headline: Clean your tools after pruning each shrub with bleach and water.
steps.description: If you need to prune multiple shrubs, clean your tools in between pruning each shrub using a solution of 1 part bleach and 9 parts water. This will prevent the spread of disease.

steps.headline: Wipe your tools to prevent rust, then store them in a dry place.
steps.description: Once you are done pruning, wipe down the metal parts of your tools with a soft, clean, lightly-oiled cloth. This will help remove all traces of moisture that could lead to rust. Store the tools someplace dry.

steps.headline: Treat common shrub rose problems.
steps.description: Shrub roses are susceptible to diseases, such as: replant disease, rose blackspot, rose dieback, rose powdery mildew, and rose rust. They can also get the following pests: rose aphids, rose large sawfly, and rose leaf rolling sawfly. If you are unsure what to use to treat these problems, head over to your local nursery and ask for advice.

steps.headline: Fertilize the shrub rose after you are done pruning.
steps.description: This will help encourage new growth. You can use any form of fertilizer you want: granular, liquid, or time-release. An 18-24-16 or 19-24-24 fertilizer will work well, but you can also use an organic or manure-based fertilizer if you prefer. How much fertilizer you apply depends on the type of fertilizer that you are using as well as the size of your shrub, so read the instructions on the package carefully.

tyn: White school glue or prune paint seal
text: Planning Ahead Prune shrub roses in late winter or early spring. This is the best time because the new buds and leaves are just starting to come in, making them distinguishable from the old growth. If you only need to deadhead your shrub rose, you should do it in late summer, right after the rose is done flowering. Get some hand pruners and loppers. Make sure that the hand pruners are made to cut canes up to ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick. If you can't get loppers, or simply don't like using them, get a small pruning saw instead. You'll need the loppers/pruning saw to cut thicker canes and stems. Protect yourself with heavy-duty gloves and safety goggles. It would also be a good idea to wear a pair of long pants and closed-toed work boots. The long sleeves and pants will protect your skin against the rose's sharp thorns, while the goggles will shield your eyes against any whipping stems. If you don't have any long-sleeved shirts, get gloves that reach your elbows. Disinfect your tools using bleach and water. You should do this even if the tools look clean; there may be bacteria on them that might infect your shrub rose. Prepare a cleaning solution using 1 part bleach and 9 parts water. Dip the tools into the solution to clean and disinfect them, then wipe them dry with a paper towel. Pruning Shrub Roses Cut at 45-degree angles, ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) above outward-facing buds. Outward-facing buds are buds that are facing you (or away from the center of the plant). The highest part of the angle should be on the same side as the bud. This will help prevent water from dripping into the bud which could lead to rot and decay. You will be using this technique for all parts of the rose, unless otherwise noted. Consider practicing on a few dead stems to get the hang of it. Don't cut closer than ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm), or you risk damaging the bud. Don't cut further either, or you risk the stem developing disease or hosting pests. Cut down diseased stems with loppers or bypass pruners. To remove all traces of the disease, and to reduce the chances of it coming back, cut the cane down to a bud that is at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) below the diseased portion. Use loppers on canes thicker than a pencil, and bypass pruners on thinner canes. Dead and diseased canes appear black or shriveled throughout. Healthy canes appear green on the outside and white on the inside. Seal your cuts with white school glue or prune paint seal. This will aid in healing and shield the cane against cane borers. You should do this for every cut you make from this point onward. Simply apply a drop of glue straight from the bottle to the cut portion of the cane. Prune paint seal is typically spray on, like spray paint. If it came in a can, you will have to apply it with a clean paintbrush. Use bypass pruners to clear crowded canes from the center. You do not have to cut all of the stems or canes in the middle of the shrub, but you should cut any that are crisscrossing or that appear crowded. Your goal here is to open up the shrub for air circulation. Make sure that your shrub looks symmetrical and balanced. Trim away all of the thin canes with bypass pruners. Locate the canes that are thinner than a pencil. Cut these canes off with a bypass pruner. If your area is prone to cane borers, it would be a good idea to seal the cut ends with white school glue or prune paint sealer. Use the bypass pruners to remove suckers. Suckers are stems that grow from the roots. They appear further from the main set of canes. You need to trim these as close to the base of the shrub as possible. If needed, dig through the soil to reach them. Be sure to cover the roots back up when you are done, however. Switch to a pruning saw and cut down the old, woody canes. Try to cut the old, woody canes as close to the base of the shrub as possible. Seal the cut ends with white school glue or prune paint seal. Old, woody canes may appear grayish. They are hard inside, and may have a visible woodgrain or mini tree rings. Clear the remaining foliage with bypass pruners. Use a rake to pull the cut foliage out from under the shrub. Throw the foliage away into a bin; do not toss it into a compost heap. Deadhead the shrub rose as needed with hand pruners or scissors. The best time to do this would be during the summer, after flowering is done. You can do it at other times during the year, however. Trim the cane down until you reach a stem with 5 to 7 leaves on it. Providing After-Pruning Care Clean your tools after pruning each shrub with bleach and water. If you need to prune multiple shrubs, clean your tools in between pruning each shrub using a solution of 1 part bleach and 9 parts water. This will prevent the spread of disease. Wipe your tools to prevent rust, then store them in a dry place. Once you are done pruning, wipe down the metal parts of your tools with a soft, clean, lightly-oiled cloth. This will help remove all traces of moisture that could lead to rust. Store the tools someplace dry. Treat common shrub rose problems. Shrub roses are susceptible to diseases, such as: replant disease, rose blackspot, rose dieback, rose powdery mildew, and rose rust. They can also get the following pests: rose aphids, rose large sawfly, and rose leaf rolling sawfly. If you are unsure what to use to treat these problems, head over to your local nursery and ask for advice. Fertilize the shrub rose after you are done pruning. This will help encourage new growth. You can use any form of fertilizer you want: granular, liquid, or time-release. An 18-24-16 or 19-24-24 fertilizer will work well, but you can also use an organic or manure-based fertilizer if you prefer. How much fertilizer you apply depends on the type of fertilizer that you are using as well as the size of your shrub, so read the instructions on the package carefully.
sentences: Planning Ahead Prune shrub roses in late winter or early spring.
This is the best time because the new buds and leaves are just starting to come in, making them distinguishable from the old growth.
If you only need to deadhead your shrub rose, you should do it in late summer, right after the rose is done flowering.
Get some hand pruners and loppers.
Make sure that the hand pruners are made to cut canes up to ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick.
If you can't get loppers, or simply don't like using them, get a small pruning saw instead.
You'll need the loppers/pruning saw to cut thicker canes and stems.
Protect yourself with heavy-duty gloves and safety goggles.
It would also be a good idea to wear a pair of long pants and closed-toed work boots.
The long sleeves and pants will protect your skin against the rose's sharp thorns, while the goggles will shield your eyes against any whipping stems.
If you don't have any long-sleeved shirts, get gloves that reach your elbows.
Disinfect your tools using bleach and water.
You should do this even if the tools look clean; there may be bacteria on them that might infect your shrub rose.
Prepare a cleaning solution using 1 part bleach and 9 parts water.
Dip the tools into the solution to clean and disinfect them, then wipe them dry with a paper towel.
Pruning Shrub Roses Cut at 45-degree angles, ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) above outward-facing buds.
Outward-facing buds are buds that are facing you (or away from the center of the plant).
The highest part of the angle should be on the same side as the bud.
This will help prevent water from dripping into the bud which could lead to rot and decay.
You will be using this technique for all parts of the rose, unless otherwise noted.
Consider practicing on a few dead stems to get the hang of it.
Don't cut closer than ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm), or you risk damaging the bud.
Don't cut further either, or you risk the stem developing disease or hosting pests.
Cut down diseased stems with loppers or bypass pruners.
To remove all traces of the disease, and to reduce the chances of it coming back, cut the cane down to a bud that is at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) below the diseased portion.
Use loppers on canes thicker than a pencil, and bypass pruners on thinner canes.
Dead and diseased canes appear black or shriveled throughout.
Healthy canes appear green on the outside and white on the inside.
Seal your cuts with white school glue or prune paint seal.
This will aid in healing and shield the cane against cane borers.
You should do this for every cut you make from this point onward.
Simply apply a drop of glue straight from the bottle to the cut portion of the cane.
Prune paint seal is typically spray on, like spray paint.
If it came in a can, you will have to apply it with a clean paintbrush.
Use bypass pruners to clear crowded canes from the center.
You do not have to cut all of the stems or canes in the middle of the shrub, but you should cut any that are crisscrossing or that appear crowded.
Your goal here is to open up the shrub for air circulation.
Make sure that your shrub looks symmetrical and balanced.
Trim away all of the thin canes with bypass pruners.
Locate the canes that are thinner than a pencil.
Cut these canes off with a bypass pruner.
If your area is prone to cane borers, it would be a good idea to seal the cut ends with white school glue or prune paint sealer.
Use the bypass pruners to remove suckers.
Suckers are stems that grow from the roots.
They appear further from the main set of canes.
You need to trim these as close to the base of the shrub as possible.
If needed, dig through the soil to reach them.
Be sure to cover the roots back up when you are done, however.
Switch to a pruning saw and cut down the old, woody canes.
Try to cut the old, woody canes as close to the base of the shrub as possible.
Seal the cut ends with white school glue or prune paint seal.
Old, woody canes may appear grayish.
They are hard inside, and may have a visible woodgrain or mini tree rings.
Clear the remaining foliage with bypass pruners.
Use a rake to pull the cut foliage out from under the shrub.
Throw the foliage away into a bin; do not toss it into a compost heap.
Deadhead the shrub rose as needed with hand pruners or scissors.
The best time to do this would be during the summer, after flowering is done.
You can do it at other times during the year, however.
Trim the cane down until you reach a stem with 5 to 7 leaves on it.
Providing After-Pruning Care Clean your tools after pruning each shrub with bleach and water.
If you need to prune multiple shrubs, clean your tools in between pruning each shrub using a solution of 1 part bleach and 9 parts water.
This will prevent the spread of disease.
Wipe your tools to prevent rust, then store them in a dry place.
Once you are done pruning, wipe down the metal parts of your tools with a soft, clean, lightly-oiled cloth.
This will help remove all traces of moisture that could lead to rust.
Store the tools someplace dry.
Treat common shrub rose problems.
Shrub roses are susceptible to diseases, such as: replant disease, rose blackspot, rose dieback, rose powdery mildew, and rose rust.
They can also get the following pests: rose aphids, rose large sawfly, and rose leaf rolling sawfly.
If you are unsure what to use to treat these problems, head over to your local nursery and ask for advice.
Fertilize the shrub rose after you are done pruning.
This will help encourage new growth.
You can use any form of fertilizer you want: granular, liquid, or time-release.
An 18-24-16 or 19-24-24 fertilizer will work well, but you can also use an organic or manure-based fertilizer if you prefer.
How much fertilizer you apply depends on the type of fertilizer that you are using as well as the size of your shrub, so read the instructions on the package carefully.
